item.title: We Are Likely Going To Get A Game Changer Or Dimension 20 Video Game In The Future
item.content:encoded:
Popular comedy streaming service and website Dropout, formerly known as College Humor, has become more and more famous online thanks in large part to its hit show Game Changer. The series, hosted by Dropout CEO Sam Reich, features comedians playing different, often complex, devious, and hilarious games each episode. Itâ€™s a great concept for a show, and I wondered if Dropout would ever make a video game version of its viral sensation. The answer: Yeah, probably!

I recently sat down and chatted with Reich as part of a larger interview about Game Changer and how the different games are designed, playtested, and balanced. And during that interview, which will be up at a later date, I had to ask if Reich and others at Dropout had ever contemplated a video game version of any of the streaming serviceâ€™s shows.

â€œYeah, for sure,â€ said Reich during our Zoom interview. He clarified that it would likely be a game based on Dimension 20, the serviceâ€™s super-popular D&D series, or one based on Game Changer. 

â€œI think that we would be into that and weâ€™ve talked about it,â€ explained the Dropout CEO and Game Changer host. â€œAnd I think itâ€™s like, at this point, itâ€™s honestly more than anything else, just like a bandwidth issue, which is if weâ€™re going to do it, we want it to feel like us, which means we need to work on it. Weâ€™re not going to farm the IP out to some third party. We want it to feel personal. And it needs to be something, therefore, that weâ€™re excited enough about and feels differentiated enough from whatâ€™s out there that it feels worth our time.â€

He also admitted that another big barrier to Dropout developing something is just how expensive games are to create and how long it takes to make them.

When I asked if Reich had really thought about this much and had some ideas for a Game Changer game, or if it was just a far-off fantasy that might happen, he confirmed that they â€œdefinitely have ideasâ€ of what a Dropout game would be, and they are working toward making one.

â€œPart of wanting to develop more of that competency was releasing all of those little web games [featured in Game Changer],â€ said Reich. â€œLetâ€™s start dabbling, you know, and like, see if we can speak this language at all.â€

In our interview, Reich sounded very confident that a Game Changer game is comingâ€¦one day, adding: â€œSo I would say we probably will do one. And itâ€™s just a question of what and when.â€

Game Changerâ€™s season 7 finale airs exclusively on Dropout on August 11.

item.title: Remembering Metal Gear Online, A Silly And Wonderful Stealth Experience
item.content:encoded:
Originally released as part of Metal Gear Solid 3: Subsistence, an augmented version of Snake Eater that hit PS2 the following year, Metal Gear Online was a strange beast. The online take on MGSâ€™ stealth gameplay would receive a few other iterations, with one accompanying Metal Gear Solid 4, another a part of the PSP titles Portable Ops and Peace Walker, and lastly with Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. (Letâ€™s not talk about Survive. It doesnâ€™t count.) For me, MGO was at its best in the version that accompanied MGS4, but in all the iterations I played, MGO remained something special, a celebration of MGSâ€™ tendency to be a little goofy and, of course, an engaging multiplayer stealth game when it (and the players) wanted it to be.

MGO arguably ushered in a new perspective for Metal Gear as it forced the series to adopt a now-standard moveable 3D camera that pivots around the character. Prior to its release, MGS used fixed camera angles, usually in a top-down or isometric perspective. That perspective wasnâ€™t ideal for a multiplayer game. At the same time, MGS is far from a fast-paced shooter. Itâ€™s slower, encouraging a more methodical approach even if youâ€™re responding to threats with lethal force. And thatâ€™s one aspect that made both traditional, single-player MGS and its online offshoots so special. Some modes of MGO encouraged a relatively hectic play style. Others, meanwhile, were almost entirely about stealth. Take â€œSneaking MIssion,â€ in which one player would take on the role of Snake as he stealthfully tried to knock out and steal dog tags from other players. Trying to stay hidden from actual flesh-and-blood players offered a kind of thrill that was quite distinct from what youâ€™d get in the single-player games.

Naturally, being a Metal Gear game, cardboard boxes, naughty magazines, exaggerated death screams, the ability to play as characters from the series, and more made the game feel like an appropriately absurd celebration of what so many of us love about these games. MGSâ€™ charm was and is never about one singular thing. Itâ€™s the sum of all of its wildly eccentric parts. That carried through in the various online modes it received over the years. I mean, just look at this nonsense. Where else would you see something like this?

Modders have recently made incredible strides in their efforts to resurrect the MGS4 iteration of Metal Gear Online on PC, so this experience is not totally lost to time. And technically you can still play MGSVâ€™s online mode, though every time Iâ€™ve tried recently, I spend more time waiting for a match than I do playing. I also never cared for its class-based character selection.

Metal Gear Online is due to return later this year though. â€œFox Huntâ€ is expected to launch in the fall as a part of the upcoming remake of MGS3, Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater. Not a whole lot about this mode is known right now, though the gameâ€™s dedicated page promises â€œhide-and-seek basedâ€ gameplay â€œthat utilizes the central elements of the base gameâ€“camouflage and survival.â€

MGO was always a niche experience, of interest to only the most passionate of us MGS dorks. Hopefully Fox Hunt will provide new, quirky experiences thatâ€™ll satisfy this discerning crowd of stealth fans.

item.title: Guy Who Wants To Turn His Viral AI Art Into A Game Explains Why Heâ€™s Not Using AI To Do It
item.content:encoded:
A software engineer who goes by Desimulate on X recently posted a five-second clip of AI-generated pixel art that went viral. Think your favorite Instagram pixel artist recreating Daggerfall with wild parallax scrolling effects. It was such a hit on Elon Muskâ€™s Grok-infested social media platform that Desimulate decided to try and actually make the game the five-second clip would be from. But heâ€™s not using AI to do it. Why? â€œWell, right now, the tools arenâ€™t really good enough.â€

Thatâ€™s what he told Ryan K. Rigney in the latest edition of the Push to Talk newsletter. Desimulate said the viral post was the result of working very closely with Midjourney, using lots of specific reference art to try and hone the outputs while also trying to spur them into generating something new. â€œI just got obsessed with making something unique, and that post was the epitome of that for me. And it kind of came out of nowhere,â€ he told Rigney.

omw pic.twitter.com/eCiTOrjtzC

â€” Desimulate (@de5imulate) July 20, 2025

But while AI can generate a five-second clip, itâ€™s nowhere near being able to generate an actual game based on it, let alone one as ambitious as an open-world fantasy RPG with extremely detailed pixel art. â€œThe meshes are probably good enough to make a basic game,â€ he explains. â€œSomething small. But this is a game that is kind of demanding, right? Itâ€™s going to be a real fantasy RPG. So at the end of the day, itâ€™s going to have to be performant. The 3D generation stuff right nowâ€¦the meshes are just not up to snuff. They are way too many triangles, polygons, and a lot of them kind of get messed up. And so it actually ends up taking more time to clean them than it would to just, like, start from the beginning. So we just use it as a visual reference.â€

Desimulate is not a game developer. Neither am I. So I canâ€™t tell you whether heâ€™s making any sense. But I can tell you that heâ€™s now trying to hire people who are game developers to turn his viral AI GIF into a game. Iâ€™ve encountered many a video game Kickstarter with vertical slices from people who have actually shipped games before that never came close to panning out. If I was a Polymarket guy, which I am definitely not, this is not the horse Iâ€™d be picking.

But I do think the interview provides a fascinating and useful look into the allure of AI tools like Midjourney and what people think theyâ€™re doing when they work with them. Itâ€™s clear Desimulate feels like he has ownership over what the machine spit out, even though his contribution to it is a rounding error in the grand scheme of things like training data. Rigney asked why heâ€™s the one to make the game imagined by the people upvoting his post. Hereâ€™s what he said:

â€œIâ€™ve got the vision, and everything starts with that vision. Iâ€™ve got the passion to make it happen. In two weeks, Iâ€™ve interviewed 40-plus people, brought a real team together of real game devs, started building, designing the game, and weâ€™ve made a ton of progress. Obviously everything is in an R&D state. But I am committed to making it happen.â€

item.title: Yup, People Are Already Using Cheats In Battlefield 6â€˜s Open Beta
item.content:encoded:
Battlefield 6â€˜s open beta launched less than 24 hours ago across consoles and PC. And already, there are numerous videos floating around that show players using cheating software that gives them an unfair advantage. This has led to a firestorm online as many PC players are upset about being forced to jump through hoops to use Secure Boot, tech designed to limit malicious activity, yet cheaters are already infesting BF6â€˜s beta.

On August 6, the highly anticipated Battlefield 6 open beta went liveâ€¦if you had an early access code. Yeah, not really an open beta, but whatever. And despite EA devoting a lot of resources to preventing players from cheating, including the required use of Secure Boot, players began sharing videos online of what appear to be people playing the beta while using wallhacks and other cheats that reveal information about enemy players that shouldnâ€™t be available. One video I found featured a montage, complete with music, of what appears to be one person killing dozens and dozens of other players across various matches and maps in the Battlefield 6 open beta.

All first-person shooters, like Counter-Strike 2, are affected by cheating âš ï¸

Despite Anti-Cheat announcements, Battlefield 6 has been affected since day one ğŸš« pic.twitter.com/cwxLPanq2N

â€” CS2 Vaccoin (@vaccoin) August 8, 2025

Another video of what appears to be a BF6 open beta cheater has racked up nearly seven million views on Twitter. The videoâ€™s popularity and the huge response to it were big enough to attract the attention of Battlefield producer Alexia Christofi, who replied and explained that the team was aware of the cheating and that she believed the player in the clip had already been banned.  So far, the cheating appears to be only on PC, though because of crossplay, these cheaters can play against Xbox and PS5 users.

Kotaku has contacted EA about the cheating seen in the videos and asked for more information on the situation.

Of course, thereâ€™s no way to completely stop people from cheating in a video game that can be downloaded locally to a PC or console. But what is angering many players online is that Battlefield 6, like the upcoming Call of Duty Black Ops 7, requires PC users to use Secure Boot. This is a relatively new technology that helps prevent malicious software from booting up on a Windows PC. Hereâ€™s how Activision describes the tech: â€œSecure Boot makes sure a PC can only load trusted software when Windows starts.â€

The problem is that on some older setups, Secure Boot requires users to screw around with their BIOS, which can cause a lot of damage to a PC if done incorrectly. I mean, look at EAâ€™s support page about Secure Boot and the steps needed just to see if the feature is active or not on your computer, and you can see why itâ€™s giving a lot of players trouble. And even if it does work, itâ€™s a lot of hoops to jump through, and the end result is that people are still cheating. BF6 isnâ€™t even out yet, just in open beta, and cheaters have, in less than 48 hours, gotten wallhacks working in the game. You can understand why some players are royally upset about the whole situation.

Vince Zampella, the head of Battlefield Studios, was asked about anti-cheat last week and said that until the â€œday we die, we will be fightingâ€ cheaters.

â€œItâ€™s a weird one, because you donâ€™t want to talk about what youâ€™re doing,â€ said Zampella in an interview with Gaming Interviews on YouTube. â€œIt gives people that are trying to cheat a head start against you. Itâ€™s a huge thing in the industry, in gaming. Itâ€™s a constant arms race that weâ€™re always putting a lot of effort into, know that. Itâ€™s something that we would stamp out completely if we could, itâ€™s just an arms race. To the day we die, we will be fighting it.â€

Updated: 8/8/2025, 4:40 p.m. ET: EA has published a forum post detailing its efforts to combat cheating in the BF6 open beta. The company explained that Secure Boot isnâ€™t and was never intended to be a â€œsilver bulletâ€ against cheating in the game. Itâ€™s just part of a larger effort to combat naughty players. EA also claims to have prevented over 300,000 attempts to cheat or tamper with Battlefield 6â€˜s open beta, and itâ€™s received over 100,000 reports of players who might be cheating. They are now working to remove those players who are actually cheating.

â€œAnti-Cheat isnâ€™t one and done,â€ explained an EA rep. â€œItâ€™s an ever-evolving battlefield, and what has worked for us previously or in different games doesnâ€™t always work in all of them. I hope this helps, and please keep the reports coming in â€“ weâ€™ll continue cleaning up the cheaters so you can have a fair game.â€
